docs.snippet: LOS ANGELES    T he wages of screenwriting in Hollywood are money and oblivion.  Actors get notoriety and adoration. Directors get retrospectives and long obituaries. Producers get sexual favors and the ability to spend conspicuously on large yach...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES T he wages of screenwriting in Hollywood are money and oblivion. Actors get notoriety and adoration. Directors get retrospectives and long obituaries. Producers get sexual favors and the ability to spend conspicuously on large yachts and beige tennis courts. Screenwriters rarely even get mentioned in the reviews.

headline.main: HOLLYWOOD SURVIVAL: 50 YEARS OF SUCCESS AND OBLIVION

docs.snippet: TIFFANY stained-glass panels crated since the 1920's and displays and photographs providing insights into Tiffany techniques and discoveries are all part of a new exhibition, ''Louis Comfort Tiffany's Brilliance in Glass,'' opening Tuesday and con...
docs.lead_paragraph: TIFFANY stained-glass panels crated since the 1920's and displays and photographs providing insights into Tiffany techniques and discoveries are all part of a new exhibition, ''Louis Comfort Tiffany's Brilliance in Glass,'' opening Tuesday and continuing through April 15 at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase. The panels, which have been in crates in the belfry of the North Baptist Church of Port Chester since it opened its current building in 1924, form part of a window 13 feet high and 5 feet wide that depicts Christ walking on water. Another window, actually a triptych of John baptizing Christ, is installed above the church's baptistery and is displayed through photographs at the Neuberger Museum. The stained-glass windows show the creative and technical brilliance of the 19th-century glass maker, who was responsible for many innovations in his field, according to Carolyn Owsianik, the exhibition's curator. Both sets of windows were created during the 1890's for the Epiphany Baptist Church in midtown Manhattan, which was razed in 1922. They were removed from the Manhattan church when its congregation relocated in 1906 and were forgotten until they appeared in Westchester in the 1920's.

docs.snippet: A State Department spokesman said today that it ''simply was not true'' that the Reagan Administration suppressed any evidence that Salvadoran exiles were living in Miami while directing the actions of death squads in El Salvador.   Robert E. Whit...
docs.lead_paragraph: A State Department spokesman said today that it ''simply was not true'' that the Reagan Administration suppressed any evidence that Salvadoran exiles were living in Miami while directing the actions of death squads in El Salvador. Robert E. White, who was Ambassador to El Salvador in the Carter Administation, said Thursday that his embassy had given the State Department specific, detailed information about the actions of six exiles, including their names, but that the information had been ignored.

headline.main: U.S. Denies Concealing Data on 6 Salvadorans

docs.snippet: A former United States Ambassador to El Salvador accused the Reagan Administration today of deliberately ignoring specific and detailed information about six Salvadoran exiles living in Miami who, he said, have been directing the actions of death ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former United States Ambassador to El Salvador accused the Reagan Administration today of deliberately ignoring specific and detailed information about six Salvadoran exiles living in Miami who, he said, have been directing the actions of death squads in their home country. The former envoy, Robert E. White, who served under the Carter Administration, identified the six exiles in testimony prepared for presentation to the House Foreign Affairs Committee's Western Hemisphere subcommittee. He said the six ''hatch plots in Miami and communicate instructions to their agent'' in El Salvador, Roberto d'Aubuisson, head of Salvador's far-right National Republican Alliance and a candidate for president. Assassination of Archbishop Mr. White also asserted that the Reagan Administration had known ''for three years that Roberto d'Aubuisson planned and ordered the assassination'' of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, which occurred in March 1980. The Archbishop was an outspoken opponent of violence.

docs.snippet: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Coastal Corporation in Houston, wants very much to acquire a natural gas pipeline company that operates within Texas.   But it looks like he will have to fight very hard to get one.    Mr. Wy...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Coastal Corporation in Houston, wants very much to acquire a natural gas pipeline company that operates within Texas. But it looks like he will have to fight very hard to get one. Mr. Wyatt's current target, the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, would meet his goal better than any other company, analysts say. And so a subsidiary of Coastal is offering to buy 45 percent of Houston Natural Gas's common stock for $68 a share. The $1.28 billion offer, made late last week, would give Mr. Wyatt a controlling interest since Coastal already owns slightly more than 5 percent of the company.

headline.main: Coastal Chief's Goal Sparks Stock Fight

docs.snippet: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, a takeover target of the Coastal Corporation, is seriously considering making a bid for Coastal as a defensive step, Wall Street professionals said yesterday.     A bid for Coastal would be extremely difficult,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, a takeover target of the Coastal Corporation, is seriously considering making a bid for Coastal as a defensive step, Wall Street professionals said yesterday. A bid for Coastal would be extremely difficult, they said, particularly because it has introduced provisions - ''shark repellants,'' in Wall Street jargon - to fight off any hostile bidder. But they said unconfirmed reports were circulating that Houston Natural Gas, whose directors met in a lengthy emergency session last night, might be willing to pay stockholders of Coastal about $40 a share.

headline.main: HOUSTON GAS MAY BID FOR COASTAL

docs.snippet: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell Guatemala $2 million worth of spare parts for its aging fleet of United States-made military helicopters, the State Department said today.   It would be the first official sale of military equipment to ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration has agreed to sell Guatemala $2 million worth of spare parts for its aging fleet of United States-made military helicopters, the State Department said today. It would be the first official sale of military equipment to Guatemala since 1977, when the military Government refused assistance after the Carter Administration strongly criticized it for human rights abuses. A department spokesman asserted that since the sale would be a cash transaction, it would not be a violation of a Congressional ban on military assistance to Guatemala. Copters Built in 1950's Guatemala's Foreign Minister, Fernando Andrade Diaz-Duran, announced the sale after a meeting with United States Ambassador Frederick L. Chapin in Guatemala on Saturday.

headline.main: U.S. AGREES TO SELL HELICOPTER PARTS TO GUATEMALANS

docs.snippet: Mae Ash used to be a maid at the Waldorf-Astoria. William McKie can tell stories about his cross-country travels. Ernest Alvizo taught school in Brooklyn. Donna Gray grew up in foster homes and has spent time in six mental hospitals.    Though the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mae Ash used to be a maid at the Waldorf-Astoria. William McKie can tell stories about his cross-country travels. Ernest Alvizo taught school in Brooklyn. Donna Gray grew up in foster homes and has spent time in six mental hospitals. Though their pasts differ, they all have one thing in common: They are among New York City's homeless men and women, people most often described in statistics - in shelter counts and budget allotments and population percentages. Behind those numbers are the names and faces and struggles in a world that exists in every part of the city, in doorways and on park benches, in shelters and church basements, in subways and train stations, on Park Avenue and on the Bowery.

headline.main: THE OTHER CITY: NEW YORK'S HOMELESS

docs.snippet: Witnesses to Evolution        DENVER  H ISTORY does not tell us who was calling fouls when the first mammals stood up on their hind legs and began to walk, but Sid Borgia and Norm Drucker were blowing the whistle when basketball evolved from the d...
docs.lead_paragraph: Witnesses to Evolution DENVER H ISTORY does not tell us who was calling fouls when the first mammals stood up on their hind legs and began to walk, but Sid Borgia and Norm Drucker were blowing the whistle when basketball evolved from the dark ages to the age of flight. These two survivors from prehistoric times were granted the honor of officiating the first National Basketball Association old-timers game yesterday - and discovered that Red Auerbach still howls when he loses. The 21 players showed flashes of their old game but Auerbach was vintage vinegar as he paced the common dressing room and snapped, ''These guys played their hearts out, they couldn't breathe, and you guys are Globetrottering it.'' Auerbach was upset because Drucker, 61, called a two-shot foul for ''unnecessary roughness'' when avocado-shaped Tom Heinsohn tried to pull down the shorts of pear-shaped John Kerr in a pivot battle of the bellies.

docs.snippet: Frank Harris was a second-rate writer and a first-rate personality from London to the Riviera in the early part of the century. He was better known as a boulevardier than anything else. If he were alive today, he certainly would be hot copy for th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Harris was a second-rate writer and a first-rate personality from London to the Riviera in the early part of the century. He was better known as a boulevardier than anything else. If he were alive today, he certainly would be hot copy for the the gossip columns. As an editor, he helped to debase the standards of several British newspapers.
